articles.article: Welcome to the Jecca tutorial. Let's assume we have used two annotators to annotate the current text. Have a look at the words in boldface like Obama referring to the president of the United States of America. When you move over it with your mouse cursor, you can see "Obama" twice, the first line corresponds to the first annotator and the second line to the second annotator. Both annotators got it right, so Obama appears in green. But Obama may also refer to his wife. In this case "Obama" got duplicated, because the annotators produced different results for it. The first annotator got it wrong (red color) and the second hasn't found it at all (purple). Move your mouse on top of a mention and a tooltip will give you details about it. Click on the first line of "Michelle Obama" to mark all the spans annotated with her. You can see in green the "chain" where the underlined span belongs to, and in red the chain to which it was wrongly attributed. Click on the underlined span or a span without a mention to go back to the normal mode.

Jecca can combine mentions either by same color or same entity. Take for example "bow", a homonym with several meanings. Both annotators misinterpreted what the author meant with this word, because he didn't put it in context. By default, Jecca combines mentions by color. Thus, since both annotator got it wrong, "bow" appears only once. However the annotators chose different (wrong) entities. The option "Combine same entities" makes Jecca duplicate the aforementioned "bow", to visualize the fact that the annotators do not agree.
Click on "Show symbols" to display a ✔, ✘ or ? symbol at the end of the spans for correct, wrong or missing annotations. When you want information about overlapping mentions, activate the "Show entity numbers" option. Mentions with the same entities get the same number, where "(" indicates the start and ")" indicates the end. The upper number of a span indicates the gold standard entity and the number at the bottom the one of the annotator.

Deselect "Anno 2" to hide the second annotator. You can still click on mentions to highlight the corresponding chains. Jecca recalculates which mentions to show in the split/compact view. If the users deselects all annotators, Jecca highlights the gold standard mentions.

Jecca shows all available evaluation metrics in the drop-down list. Choose your preferred metric to see the computed precision and recall. Jecca highlights the best annotator for recall and precision respectively.
